lead_paragraph: A Federal appeals court ruled today that the Government must place thousands of acres of Southern California coastal brushland under special scrutiny to protect a rare songbird. In March 1993, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service declared the coastal California gnatcatcher a threatened species but refused to designate land crucial to its survival. The agency said a designation might prompt some people to destroy gnatcatcher sites and would not help a majority of the birds, which live on private land not subject to Federal regulation.
abstract: Federal appeals court, 2-1, rules Fish and Wildlife Service must place thousands of acres of Southern California coastal brushland under special scrutiny to protect coastal California gnatcatcher, rare songbird (S)

headline.main: Appeals Court Orders Protection of a Songbird
